alwaies agreeable whereas men naturally desirous souereine welfare highest felicitie cheefe good howbeit fewe doe knowe wherein consisteth right way leadeth thereunto yet withstanding without knowledge trueth wisedome mere ignorance blyndnesse folly goodnesse mere corruption wickednesse al brauerie tryumphe iollitie pompe vtter miserie wretchednesse present worke treateth trewnesse say perpetuall inuariable constancie sted fastnesse christian religion band linketh god vnto man men one another vnto god lampe enlighteneth man wit true wisedome onely waterspring replenisheth true goodnesse mightis power giueth strength courage man spirit whereby enabled perfectly discerne beholde souereine welfare felicitie god founder furtherer finisher trueth rather trueth selfe constantly reason herewithall thought also men haue either meane come bookes leysure read whose labour haue meane eased oftentimes driuen doo one chapter whereof others haue made whole volume conclude pray reader first read booke throughout without mounting degree man cannot attaine high thing breaking ladder steale casteth man backe maketh thing wearisome easie secondly desire bring wit rather reading thereof foredeemings foresetled opinion doo bring bondage reason haue best wit wheras notwithstanding belongeth ouerrule wit wit guide thirdly beseech beare alwaie mind man among men one least say satisfie point reason attaineth eueriewhere far truth doth end mine ignorance weakenesse preiudice case mine vndertaking whereof good sooth vpon trust mine owne wit mine owne abilitie vpon assured trust cleernesse soundnesse substantialnesse soothnesse thereof god vouchsafe shead blessing vpon worke furtherance thereof glad beleeue confirme wauer confute go shake downe doctrine onely pleasure desire onely fruit seeke labour say truth feele alreadie effect contentment thereof hart lette v praie also vouchsafe day touch stonie hart force spirit owne finger plant doctrine deeply may take god created world nothing say without matter substance stuffe whereof make god prouidence gouerneth world thing therein euill seemeth bee worlde subiect god prouidence man wisedome hath acknowledged god prouidence howe wadeth betweene destinie fortune man soule immortall immortalitie soule hath bene taught auncient philosopher beleeued nation man nature corrupted hee himselfe fallen first thereof euery men feele thereof themselues yee looke vpward yee see infinite body infinite mouings diuers yet trubling one another yee looke downeward yee see sea continuasly threatening earth yet thing therefore cannot bring foorth themselues consequently much lesse bring foorth thing remaineth notbeeing notliuing notsensible notreasonable afore beeing liuing sensible reasonable yet notwithstanding wee haue beeing life sence reason followeth therefore power without v hath brought v notbeeing beeing hath parted said gift among v diuerlly according good pleasure otherwise nothing fruitfull vncosumable might whence commeth perfection singular wisedome plant hot cold sweete bitter nourishing healing daungerous remedie found either themselues next vnto also touching beastes like thy selfe yet touching bodie thou seest thing altered partes thereof death neither within without soule hast thou euer seene thou beleeue therof effect thou seest cannot come thing el assure thee euen effect thou beleeue nothing thereof thou seest thyne eye thyne eye see thy soule thyne eye themselues see thy soule short thou beleeuest thou hast face without looking glasse thou seest wilt thou thing sunnebeames man artes science therefore let v see whether artes science guyde v vnitie whereunto action nature thing haue led v alreadie beginning lower mounting vp higher grammer teacheth v bring diuers part speech oue congruetie end thereof speake end speaking societie rhetorike teacheth drawe mennes mind one selfsame opinion logike teacheth sift ye trueth nober falshods treuth one end tendeth preseruation restitution health health nothing el welproportioned vnion diuers humor togither skill lawe tendeth right one right though infinite wrong serues mainteyne restore bring men backe ageine vnto vnitie let v proceede morall philosophie subdeweth many diuers passion affection vnto one reason one man shold gouernment bringeth many men obeying one householder ciuillgouernment reduceth many household one commonweale nothing vnitie many people whether vnder one lawe vnder one magistrate insomuch eue popular comonweales haue extremity taken dictator ordinarie course gouernment consull one euer man conceiueth inuenteth disposeth doth leade v alwayes vnitie vnitie lost thing goe wrecke artes confounded commonweales dissolued like vnvnited diuersitie wee finde waste subuersion must looke vnity increase preseruation thing man within man without doe leade v one alone shall suffer himselfe raunge vnto many sonnebeames man meane art science tend one vnitie shall diuinitie turne v aside pluralitie goddes nay rather many vnities make v stye vp true perfect vnitie vnitie onely one god let v see thing diuers whole worlde referred one another water moysteneth earththe linking thing together ayre maketh fatte shower sunne inlighteneth heateth according season earth nourisheth plant plant eede beastes beast serue man againe nothing seene made itselfe sunne shineth heateth selfe earth heareth yet hath benefite thereby wind blowe yet sayle thing redound glory maker accomplishment whole benefite man short noblest creature haue neede bacest bacest serued noblest linked together highest lowest ring thereof cannot bee broken without confusion sunne cannot eclipsed plantes withered raine want thing feele hurt thereof imagine woorke consisteth many diuers peeces tending one end cuppled one another making one body ful apparant consent affection proceedeth elsewhere power one alone feeld see many battels diuers standerds sundry liueries yet turning head selfe serue vnderstandeth meaning wee wonder world world sake selfe rather woorkemaister author world manifest childishnes woonder portraiture made peinter woonder much peynter himselfe first consideration offereth selfe beholder woorke whether hath beginning question perchaunce vnnecessarie behalfe euery man would consult owne reason whereunto nothing repuguant thinke eternitie bee thing wee onely perceiue sences also doe see perish howbeit forasmuch world speaketh sayth psalmist language nation let v examine whole together according seuerall part thereofthe world selfe telleth v beginning may worldling distrust owne record leastwise admit world selfe shall depose thereof let v examine element together passe one another earth water water ayre ayre water againe foorth intercourse cannot made tyme tyme measuring mouing measure eternitie let v examine seuerally earth hath season springtime commeth sommer sommer succeedeth haruest haruest followeth winter sea hath continuall ebbing flowing goeth increasing decreasing certeyne measure diuers riuers especially nyle haue increasings certeyne season certeyne measure cubit ayre also hath windes doe one cleere another trubble windes doe reigne turnes blowing sometime east sometime west sometime north sometime south vppon dependeth rayne faire wether stormes calmes interchaunges wrought turnes cannot bee without beginning order formernesse afternesse chaunge kind mouing insomuch alteration made successiuely one another must necessitie haue beginning poynt land one season sea ebbing flowing ayre north south foorth began one poynt could hold vnto poynt land season ayre chaunges sea tydes ceasse crye preach vnto haue eares heare euerlastingnesse haue beginning againe consider earth receyueth season sunne sea tydes moone ayre windes outward power vnseene ought wee seeke beginning thereof aboue beneath without within seeing nothing heere belowe hath mouing selfe element accounted ground beginning thing acknowledge beginning mouings ought acknowledge ye thing consider moone maketh tydes sea hath light sunne maketh season earth doe conclude season earth tydes sea continnall chaunges mouings ye tyme followe forenesse afternesse continuance mouing implyeth manifest contrarietie definition mouing place place tyme beginninglesse el say tyme tyme ye would say implying contradiction word self el tyme according aristotle himselfe number mouing forenesse afternesse past come number infinitenesse thereof become afore eternitie thereof another place sayth mouing eternall tyme eternall cause time alwaies ioyned past pray childishnesse reason may say mouing mill stirring liuing wight eternall case euery instant followeth immediatly necke past lesse mouing tyme yet wee bee ignorant haue beginning like certeyne first forthsetting also mouing heauen breeder tyme algazel algazel answereth auerrhois well vpon poynt looke poynt pricke thing hold whole vnbroken instant moment thing immediatly continually succeede one another poynt pricke beginning lyne instant beginning tyme auerrhois could disproue reason otherwise flowring replyeth yet agayne sayth yea world beginning shall maker thereof voyd alteration question thinkes himselfe answere thus alledging incouenience assoyleth question good sir philosopher seeking bring v inconuenience graunt leastwise god created nature straunge ouersight needes tye lawes nature maker nature measure power libertie clockmaker subiection clocke vnto art thou ashamed yeeld lesse preheminence god thy king thou exemptest subiection lawes maker lawes pray thee thing thou shouldest vndertake measure nature thyne owne wit number tymes hast thou found thy wit stumble least thing often hast thou found thy selfe nature goe beyond reach thy wit farre shall maker nature outgoe thou canst shift thy place without remouing therefore thou deemest like god consider leastwise soule mynd limited within place place thousand thing thousand thing place thereof againe thy soule cannot conceiue thing without passing contemplation action abyde contemplation without chaunge thy desire haue god like thy self behalf thou wilt yeeld thy self men reason leastwise yeeld thy selfe thyne owne reason wheras thou sayst beyond heauenaristotle first booke heauen cap neither emptinesse tyme whatsoeuer exempted maner tyme mouing chaunge passibilitie comparison betweene god thee yet haue thing doth somewhat resemble thee thou chaungest thy another thing thy thing thou amost thy selfe thing cannot chaunge thee therefore thou art fayne chaunge also thou chaungest beholding thing thou beholdest thou beholdest two bee short beholding thou doest sort suffer thing thou beholdest thou sufferest thing thou doest vnto maker al thing behold behold doe faultie prouidence sith fooles must answered folly least thinke themselues wise wisdome folke consisteth togither putting foorth question answering nothing let v examine goodly demaunds ouer poynt poyntthe obiection moutaines prouidence say whereto serue mountaines nay say rather one sort prouidence el prouidence disposing many sundrie thing one ende ca disposing one selfsame thing euerywhere throughout bruite beast thou art would ant speake thee would aske whereto serued rising thy nose aboue thy face thy browes aboue thyne eye thy ribbes aboue rest thy bodie higher aboue thy bodie mountaines aboue plaines earth thou esteemest greatly beautie thy face proportion thy bodie insomuch thou fallest euen loue another yet thou wilt finde fault whole world deformitie want order thou lucrece durst thou pray thee bee bolde speake painter would offend thee another man speake grossely thy bookes man finde fault shadowing picture table would answered shoomaker ought presume aboue pantople without blacke white could haue grace neither could bright bee set without dimming difference proportion part appeare without medley contrary resemblance finally unning painter perceiued without diuersitie colour also finde fault art thy booke hauing red peeces bee answered lawyer man cannot iudge lawe without reading wholly throughout happen absurditie start vp whole world gramarians inforce wittes vttermost excuse finde elegancie thyne vncongruities alledging vnseemly part beautifieth whole worke shadowe perfect colour dimme bright fitly placed commendation paynted thing consisteth diuersities insomuch thou see playne ouerhanged shadie rocke dankish denne head riuer springing thou likest better table praysest paynter skill surely possible playne please thee hilles riuer rockes neither without could please thee thou diddest consider world worke god mountaines part thou mislikest themselues small peeces worke doubtlesse thou wouldest say much thereof therefore sith thou canst one view behold whole world together iudge proportion whole masse seuerall part thereof one instant learne commend cunning workmaister thing thou thinkest thy selfe vnderstande rather call question thing thou vnderstandest let v see reason thou hast complaine thou wouldest shunne rayne hayle frost behold mountaynes furnish thee wood timber house thee shelter thee make thee warme thou followest commoditie traffick behold serue thy turne riuers east west north south making way middest land sea ioyning coastes sea land together ambition thy neighbour suspected thee thyne perchaunce noysome vnto high mountaines bound separate nation asunder keepe incroching one vpon another omit wine fruit yeeld foorth clere water shed flockes heards cattel feede pleasant dwelling conuey thou couldest finde many thing thy bare playne alone would giue thee leaue complayne mountaynes nay contrary parte thou haddest felt discommodities playnes lybie onely playnes beawsse desert champayne thou wouldest wish mountaynes yet notwithstanding playne al hilground thou couldest tell commend discommend eyther let stand answere philosopher take vppon controll part worke conceyue whole blame whole world mountaynes sake mountayne wood grow thereon one ye finde fault whole man lesse wert heare yet notwithstanding old man thou honorest heare barber cutteth casteth fire yea thou honorest olde man let v proceede rest argument thou complaynest wilde beasteswyld beastes hath made wild thy selfe nay rather thou shouldest wonder prouidence god apollonius hath well marked hath printed awe man hurt vnlesse bee assaulted pinched extreme hunger therein man would like extremitie thou hast yet cause wonder prouidence beastes might hurt thee go single alone themselues haunt couerts caues earth make small increase whereas beast thy benefite huge strong soeuer come home familiarly thee submitting themselues whole flockes heards childe increasing thousand within small tyme tell good earnest worke fortune beastes may anoy thy life doe shunne thee whose life thou maynteynest thyne owne life come offer themselues vnto thee sea displeaseth thee occupying much ye earth wart thou dweller sea thou art ye land earth would displease thee occupying much seathe sea aristotle concludeth prouidence bycause earth vncouered sea hygher element wold else ouerwhelme booke woonders yet deale thereof still emptie sit inhabited know thou thou art beholden great number liuing wight fostereth thee great number townes city inricheth thee nauigations whereby shorteneth thy way yeeldeth thee trafficke vapor wherwith mainteyneth ayre maketh earth fat put case sea dryed vp instant number city thinkest thou seene desolate nation desert men bee case drought fish left drye ground going away tyde shouldest thou rather commend beneficialnes thereof thinking enough lend selfe thee doe thee seruice otherwise also teacheth thee mightie prouidence prouident might made whe thou seest ouerdreepe earth threaten drowning euery minute hower yet able passe bound thou seest seeke inuyron great countrey round though imbrace yet stay narrowe balke el winde selfe bowelles land narrowe chanell whereas notwithstanding infinite sort little iles settled middest deepe like sort small mote pond seeing thou seekest thy commoditie profite thereby thinkest thou also seeketh glorie though thou haddest none profite much thee haue ground matter wherfore magnifie windesthe wynd perchaunce make thee hate thou must needes haue saying yet side hold calme thou art weary couldest thou without haue knowne tenth part earth couldest thou haue discouered land perow iles moluckes nay couldest thou haue come nerest iles vnto thee without thou like wind fauourable thee another man hath doe contrary coast like well contrary thee finde fault storminesse thereof knowe ye made wilbe glorifyed thereby doth thee vnderstand able meete thee sea land thou art taught call vpon selfesame winde hath caryed thee thy pleasure readie dash thee land little drye ground remaineth two part sayst thou vnhabitablethe earth vnhabitable tolde thee nay rather doest thou couclude therevpon creator seeing euen thy tyme part inhabited surely wind thou blamest much haue taught v clymates goodly country people better health greater strength wee beautifull city delicate fruites wee finde temperate forsake temperatest country goe thether day yeeres measured otherwise one countrie another yet varietie constancie one selfesame sunne maketh many diuersities doth thee vnderstand made sunne could well make thing bee short great eunning thing thou hast bene inforced make arte learning el arte setting diuers rule order together arte bee needfull knowing say much arte thing selfe thou blamest thornes bryers bush couering earth thou considerest many mischiefes ydlenesse plungeth thee thou blamest frost snowe hindering thy husbandrie whereas deede twitch thee eare put thee mynd foyzon earth commeth god thou blamest rayne wetting thee whereas yet notwithstanding moysteneth thy ground make fat worde thou playest babe thinkes nurce wrong kembes head put cloathes rather sometymes pluck firesticke take knife hand say thou misconstrewest al good bountifull prouidence god doth vnto thee end sayst thou able help selues assoone bornethe birth man bee wee subiect many disease end death presse thee speake hereafter namely thing none blame thy selfe euen thing thou findest fault shewe thee still thy face prouidence god babe borne without abilitie helpe hath none skill crye contrarywise bruite beast sooner come damme able goe yet notwithstanding babe thy seeming forlorne thing none dyeth want nurce nourishment though nothing payn care bringing vp therfore must needes follow euen beginning certeyne prouidence hath watched ouer hath ingrauen kindly affection carefulnesse mother breast lesse babe themselues manifestly doth god power shine foorth prouyding bruite beast requisite brought world sort forasmuch vnable conceiue reason interest knowledge thing touching diseasessiknesses disease thou blame season yeere thou mayst well blame fire burning thee yet notwithstanding thou canst forbeare fault thyne owne vndiscreetnesse nature thyne vnrulinesse distemperance selfsame heate wherwith thou findest fault ripeneth corne wine fruites wherewith part world fed thou thinke man therby cast agew might haue forborne haue gone sunne could haue forborne shining sunne vpon earth father housholds haue roddes hand correct child withal part gouernment consist therein thinkest thou straunge hath set v world haue meanes v awe bring v home wilt thou say number disease certeine fruit vice sinnes one drunkennesse another lecherie forth wilt thou say hippocrates himselfe speaking ordinarie sore disease inioyneth phisition wise consider well whether peculiar stroke god say whether sicknesse disease bee extraordinarie proper nerest cause thereof hand god vpon party furthermore nothing disorder wretchednesse world blamest thou death maketh thee depart bee thou hast goodes thou art loth forgo thou must consider thy parent giuen place thee order nature goodes bene none thyne death maketh cleane riddance thing thinke also maketh place moe spring vp place yet thou wouldest consider often men goe seeke death seemeth doluen deepe yet finde many meete bankets feastes mariages triumphes would faynest forget many dye yoong good health many liue fore diseased euen depth olde age many returne safe cruell battels dye beddes many dye battell fray haue shunned strife tumult life bene made immortall rather mortall bene much better also say earth rather bin fire earth eare rather bene eye eare seeing one excellent opinion philosopher better haue quality actiue passiue earth bin fire couldest thou haue rested thyne eares bene eye become thy speech yea thy reason therefore friend giue world leaue world wit disposing diuers thing order many degree euery kinde thing hath bound buttelles accordingly god hath listed appoynt thereto plant plant doth liue grow sence also beast beast beast liueth hath sence proceeded farre haue reason also man man reasoneth discourseth man therto vnchaungeable god therefore demaundeth plant hath sence man immortall world demaundeth plant plant man man short cause hath pleased god set diuers string world tune make one harmonie insomuch whosoeuer taketh away diuersitie thing taketh away world selfe poynt whereon greatly stand well say admit diuine prouidence haue stablished world yea haue vniuersall care thereof yet toyle self carke thereby selfesame sunne giueth light skye pearceth ye darke cloudes foggie mistes dryeth vp drawghts sink sheadeth foorth beames euen thing seeme filthie lothly yet himselfe blemished defiled good opinion wisdome thinke tell tyme pay hyre although let wicked walk large vppon stage godly lye prison also prouide end braueries one sort iust punishment wofull complaintes sort ioyfull triumph tragedie playd afore thee thou art offended thing thou hearest two howres space thou hast shewed vnto thee dooings ten twelue yeres rauishing helen punishment paris miserable end herod vpon murdering iohn baptist insomuch although thou bee acquainted storie yet arte thou perceiuest end thou expectest make thee beare matter commend thing otherwise thou wouldest thinke vniust also cruell gouerner stage much oughtest thou refreine thy mislyking thou considerest world kind stageplay nueied certeine end excellent maker excellent order wouldest thou see thou mightest behold age alteration thereof com e one day yea successe one onely nation hundred yeres lesse interuiewe two seruaunts comedie thou hast seene pompey ouercome loe discord offendeth thine eares thou hast seene caesar bring home sword bathed bloud senate thou child thou weepest thou beest man thou pacifyest child attendest knitting vp matter iudgement poet herevpon chorus singeth maketh pawse whyle poet seemeth haue forgotten aboue world one day stabbed infinite wound whereby little one soeuer thy child hath perceiuerance forecast poet doest thou see againe wee bee like child would controll song age one note long oration one letter wheras notwithstanding life respect whole world lesse short minim comparison whole song thou christian thou readest history ioseph thou readest sould aegipt thou canst angry inough brother sufficiently bewayle poore olde father againe cast deepe dungeon recompence chastitie thou couldest find thy heart blame pharao euen god thou seest taken prison reade king dreames within fewe dayes king aegipt succour father old age rayser vp agayne whole house neede thou perswadest thy selfe made reigne aegipt suffer sold aegiptians made deliuerer house also make bee solde bondage afore brother bee short discord offended thee harmonie delighteth thee agayne proceede one selfesame musition howbeit afore wee conclude matter see agayne much vpright thou art towards thy prince towards god thou seest great number armie come home wounded thou bee man must needes greeue thee anon one brings thee home thyne owne sonne dead thou bee father thou canst forbeare teares neighbour thyne assureth thee slayne duetie getting victorie countrie though thou take comfort first brunt yet leastwise thou wilt bee mad lay blame thy prince within thou fallest considering fruite victorie hath greeued thee forgoe thy sonne wilt thou thanke god dyed defence countrie part noble seruice shall god haue great preheminence setting foorth glorie king obteining victory god ouer creature king ouer subiects shall haue much patiece death bring vp dye seruice dye honour prince shall wee haue lesse trust touching imploying good purpose wee haue king prince captaines knowe issue owne enterprise leastwise parte knowe ne haue care life death serue let suffize answer vexe themselues either owne affliction sodayne death loue esteeme let v consequently see satisfie greeued prosperitie slowe punishmentthe slowe punishment wicked wicked thou sayst wicked haue welfare king cyrus opinion punishment people citie sardis commaunded spend tyme gaming feasting nay thou shouldest rather say haue miserie good thing thou termest good wee count neither good euill doe hand wicked turne euill well sayst thou howsoeuer termed haue great commodity world wilt thou say owne wicked disposition owne sinne work mischiefe harmes euilles thou bewaylest good men sith greater mischiefe wicked commodity thou enuyest haue little force euil harber within ueluet pantoples haue gowte dyademes headach purple robe collicke gesse thou canst feare agewfits susteyne following wicked lust namely haunting harlot man ryding commit robberie one poysoning owne brother may succeede kingdome another ridding good commonwealemen way may mainteyne himselfe still tyrannie consider miserie indure afore come performance euill abyde therof turmoyle owne conscience maketh haue performed thou shalt see continuall feuer straunge vnquietnesse sharpe sorrowe much alway daungerous shamelessest dareth bewray disease phisition alexander ye tyrant pherey wont euen chiefe prosperitie get himselfe within mote drawe vp bridge went lye concubine dennis sicilie afrayd put barber trust trimming beard made owne daughter supplye office growing afterward ielozie findged himselfe burning firebrand another oft went bed wife searched whether knife hidden bosome thinke happiest tyrant miserable person oppressed vnder tyrannie saw e thinke dennis eate deynties imagined himselfe haue naked sword hanging continually heare poynt ouer head sate table seneca thebais feare shalbe punished right sore shall reigne punishment thou dout thereof beleeue father graundfather stout triumph yea come crownes thing othersome come gallowes doth greatly skill thinke whether man tormented coate ueluet coate canna whether manacled fettered gyues gold yron whether short showe play great lord poore begger often hast thou seene cutpurse hanged purse necke theefe hanged apparell stolne thou high low degree thou rich poore thou prince peazant assoone thou hast giuen ouer thy selfe vyce wickednesse thou art become prisoner slaue skilles thou thou bee thyne owne man whereto serues thee thou art wicked deed wretched although vyce bee punishment selfe sayth hesiodus spring vp misdeede self yet notwithstading many men cannot content themselues god learning whereas thou knowest proue afterward yet thinkest thou doest hurt rather good seruice thy commonweale god knoweth ground euill selfe beareth bramble thistle want husbanding knoweth euery mynds afore wee selues knowe thing doe tyme come bee present sight thing haue done alreadie neither nero fiue yeeres good behauiour constentine wicked disorder yoonger tyme could beguyle god though thou seest outwarde man callest one father countrie vnkindly murtherer knoweth tamed woolfe turne agayne kynd churlish dogge put churlishnes foreknoweth men nature seede whereas scarce know flower whereas wee play blinde barber countrie hauing recourse euery instant searing cutting launcing sawing euery fore hath thousand receyts heale vyces withall thousand kynds scurges correct offender withall according euery complexion thinkest thou neglecteth cure thou seest fearing yron hand potential surgions terme stronger thyne actuals thou seest sinfull person cured maner without launcing yea without scarce oughtest thou commend curing thereof much amend whit delay punishment admit yet number also doe amend nay consider yet whether bee suffered liue punish thee thee say hast bene scurged alreadie yet art neuer whit amended thou wouldest haue thy father throwe rodde fire thou hast still curst heart cannot yeeld aske forgiuenesse blame thyne owne stubbornnesse burneth rodde consider also whether bee greater punishment liue haue done amisse haue dyed deede forsomuch see slaughter haue successe according willes mischiefe haue wrought vayne haue prouoked god whole world themselues purpose haue gotten nothing therby shame reproach torment mynd whether god doe meane compell crye wee haue wearyed selues way wickednesse vntill wee god say seeming flowe doe amend thee punish doest euill hath susteyned hauing goodes much euill hath endured doe euill let remember greatly hath tyred himselfe owne wish tormented himselfe good success set himselfe fire thought warme wandered quite away ment haue brought others bent owne bowe one seareth god let cosider much euill hath left vndone forbearing haue great store false goodes many thing hath wished would haue eschewed foreknowen issewe sawe afterward greatly bene dreaded misliked others though could deuise haue done better often falles slidings haue serued make take sure footing sinne oft wa derings way haue made escape lying wayt theeueries world oft owne wyles haue serued turne right often owne ouersights haue serued bring intended ende doubt heedfull marking thing others make perceyue certeyne euerlasting prouidence watcheth ouer liues doings leastwise vnlesse denye leade forecastes others another end purposed bring vnaduised ouersights others better passe themselues could wish make wisdome wisest doe seruice owne diuine wisdome man may terme also oftentymes euen vndiscreetnesse meanest worke prouidence xiij chapter man wisedome hath acknowledged god prouidence wadeth betwene destinie fortune like men olde tymethe men old tyme haue acknowledged ye maker world expresse termes othersome co sequence haue also easely perceiued prouidence thei haue deemed depend vpon appurtenance thereunto insomuch euen haue flatly denyed creation haue neuerthelater graunted prouidence reason found cleere manifest matter howbeit denye prouidence denye creation one hermes espyes euerywhere well creation whole part thereof preserued god prouident goodnesse gracious wisedome doe watch ouer thing againe plato setteth downe god bee end man man bee end thing world world selfe hee sheweth sufficiently man tendeth god doth affection ground much inclyned meanes inconueniences make fooles doubt god prouidence doe confirme wise folke therein man would bee contented part hence found aduersitie therefore thought ruler lower region meaneth feends first founder prosperity comon sort maketh great account purpose bewitch men lull sleepe hierocles also hauing made long discourse hierocles concludeth fall aduersitie whereof wee cannot coniecture cause behoueth consider wee bee ignorant thing yet must proceede farre say god author euill hath care v sayth ouergreate blasphemy aristotle aristotle moralles nicomachus eudemus speaketh otherwyse eyther greate moralls little moralls howbeit hee graueled metaphysiks howsoeuer case stand booke concerning world graunteth vnto god care al greate thing thinke beseemeth man set bound wisdome god hath limited nature thing appoynt god shall esteeme greate small nothing greate small neuerthelesse whereas sayth world dependeth vpon god end thereof best desciples infallible consequence gather thereof prouidence god seeing world dependeth vpon hym tendeth vnto beginning direction cannot proceede tendeth agein seeing sayth place kynd thing tend one perticular ende euery one peculiar selfe meete togither one vniuersall end yet haue reason vnderstanding appoynt ende themselues hold themselues within bound followeth certeine prouidence hath reason euery reason resteth god vpon al depend aristotle best lerned interpreter constrained confesse short quick sentence attributed vnto require proofe god prouidence answered lasshes whippe doth giue v sufficient credit opinion opinion theophrastus cannot doubt graunteth creation thing cannot doubt prouidence considering power goodnes alike equall behold heere ye expresse word alexander aphrodise booke prouidencealexander aphrodise booke prouidence god haue wil sayth care thing heere beneath farre disagreeing nature propertie enuious person vnable vnseemely able doe hath yet done therefore let v dout either one let v rather conclude hee haue care thing done heere belowe another place hee gathereth conclusion welfare lyeth seruing god feare gift voutsafeth extend prouidence vnto v opinion plutarke seneca owne bookes doo expresly testifie namely plutarks treatise concerning slowe punishment euill doer senecaes bookes concerning benefitesseneca concerning benefit lib cap treatise concerning prouidence lykewise doth wise philosopher epictetus vpon whome simplicius hath written many forespeeches concerning greatnes maiestie god weakenes man assayed yeelde reason thing offended weaker sort case yea euen accident thunderclap desire reader take peynes reade whole may see conformable thing whiche christian teache wisedome best sort among heathen wherevnto may income adde oracle apollo himselfe reported porphyrius man hyde god cunning deuize man slyghts suttle shift blind dim eye place fulfillethporphyrius collectios philosophy oppianus nonlatin alphabet present euerywhere giueth lyfe euery thing mooues lyfe doth beare concerning people earth whose behalfe poet full saying euery may answere orpheus homere hesiodus aratus sophocles phocylides others surely much wee see nation haue religion visible president god prouidence beleeued receiued one accord vayne doe meu serue god see vayne doo men pray regard vayne complaine hee iudge short vayne doe wee call vppon sea say soule dyeth sences seeing true sences growe increase instrument sence doe dye thing say beast dead hath lost eye selues see liueth hath forgone eye also haue prooued soule neither body appertnance body sith measure thing body measureth al body make dye body whereby body dyed yea many hundred yeeres agoe doe certeine maner liue still hurt thing nothing hurteth hindereth bodie though man lose arme yet doth soule abide whole still let forgoe one halfe body yet soule sound afore whole selfe whole euery part selfe vnited felfe owne substance force power thereof sheadeth selfe part body though body rot away peecemeale yet abideth soule one vndiminished let blud dreyne mouing wex weake sences fayle strength perish yet abideth mynd neuerthelesse sound liuely euen ende house must bee pearced side ere bee discouraged walles must battered doune ere fall fleeting neuer forsaketh lodging till roome left lodge true brute beastes forgo life action blud soule wee consider matter well gathered home self sences quenched doth labour surmount selfe woorking goodly action tyme body poynt fayle yea oftentymes farre goodlyer also euer whole lifetyme thereof example taketh order selfe houshold commonweale whole kingdome vprightnesse godlynesse wisedome moderation euer afore yea perchance body forspe bare consumed withered without putrified within whosoeuer lookes vpon see nothing earth yet heare speake would rauish man vp heauen yea aboue heauen man see liuely soule weake wretched body may say said hatching chicken shell broken commeth forth chicken also let v see ordinary cause thing perish fire doth eyether goe want nourishment quenched contrary water water resolued aire fire contrary cause plant dyeth extremitie colde drought vnseasonable cutting vyolent plucking vp also liuing wight dyeth contrarietie humour want foode feeding vpon thing nature outward vyolence cause choose haue power soule say soule man notwithstanding vnited matter bodie selfe substance vnbodily vnmateriall conceiuable vnderstanding contrarietie thing nay contrarie lodgeth contrary alike equally himselfe vnderstandeth one coucheth vnder one skill bee short contrariety themselues abandon contrarietie doe pursewe insewe one another fire hote water cold body mislike contrary greeued mynd linketh together without eyther burning cooling selfe setteth one knowe better thing destroy one another whole world mainteine one another mynds againe nothing contrary peace warre yet man mynd skill make mainteyne peace preparing warre lay earnestly warre seeking inioying peace euen death selfe dispatcheth life cannot bee contrary life soule seeketh life death death life thing meete withall whole world may bee able ouerthrowe inioyne obedience thing contrary want foode want foode world skill feede whole world forsake foode fuller much hungryer hath digested better able digest bodily wight feedeth vppon certeyne thing mynd feedeth vpon thing take sensible thing thing vnderstanding abyde still bereaue earthly thing heauenly remayne abundantly short abridge worldly thing yea world selfe euen doth feede greatest ease maketh best cheere agreeable owne nature also bodily wight filleth selfe certeyne measure delighteth certeyne thing fill mynd fill full ye knowledge thing still eager sharpe set receyue taketh still craueth yet al neuer feeleth rawnesse lack digestion shall say thing liueth deede vppon thing wonder beneath vphild el vyolence iustling two body together betweene bodie spiritual substance yea two spirit one another seeing oftentymes would destroye one another vphold one soule cannot pushed neither inwardly outwardly thing nature naturally hurt may perchaunce bee weakened force encounter wee see doth befall sences excellent sensible thing kynd ye sence receiueth much also sence self offended greeued therwith example feeling fire taste harshnesse smelling sauours hearing hideousnesse noyse whether thunderclappe falling riuer sight looking vpon sunne hande drawe v atteynement thereof dimsighted wee forbid behold thing ouerbright rawest capacitie wee offer thing vnderstandable sence beginneth perceyue sharply fayne giue ouer felt death selfe worketh according proper therof perfecteth operation thing perfecteth thereof also followeth therefore sith separation body soule forme matter perfecteth operation working soule haue sayd afore doth also make perfect strengthen thereof therefore cannot wise corrupt el dying corrupted el corrupting suffering el suffering receyuing receyueth thing without suffering receyue corruption thing fyre corrupteth marreth body suffer receyuing doth also extreme colde wee suffered nothing could freese v sences likewise marred excessiue force thing light vpon receyue perceyue thing greeueth maner beginneth beginneth cheef strength mynd houbeit men chinnes couered downe also beard become gray whose mind want exercise shewe signe either rypenesse growing moreouer time respect body cannot called ageyne respect mynd alwayes present yea tyme perfecteth accomplisheth increaseth mynd sort reneweth refressheth day day whereas contrarywise forweareth wassheth away quight consumeth self body life thereof followeth reasonable soule subiect time consequently chaunges corruption accompanye tyme nay may say thus much nothing whole world nurrished thing better neither dooth conteyne greater thing surgion cut sence plucketh hand fire yet selues put fire bare skin see sceuola burne owne hand without much gnashing teeth would thinke vtterly senslesse mightily dooth reason ouerrule sence short ending wee knowe nature away infinite thing therefore liue body yes say haue proued world beginning substantiall reason thou art able disproue therefore followeth inconuenience thou alledgest haue well proue wee selues wee neuer went thether againe intercourse betweene thing haue body thing haue body betwene heauen earth considering small intercourse euen betweene men liue vnder one selfsame sunne made magistrate countrey doth willingly returne place banishment likewise soule lodged lappe god come home natiue soyle forgoeth desire lower thing sight beholding fro aboue lesse point needle bycause swoord fall hand hand becommeth lame therefor cannot good honest man still reported bee nay though lose instrument yet ceasseth therefor bee honest man yea swoordplayer luteplayer respect skill lykewyse soules haue forgone exercise yet ceasse afore inlyghten poynt yet power soule exercysed instrument bodie othersome without help furtherance bodie atall exercysed bodie sences power sences power growing may carye likenesse betweene luter lute breake luters lute cunning remayneth still putting practise faileth giue another lute falles playing newe againe put man eye yet abilitie seeing abydeth still though act seeing bee disappoynted giue vnto oldest hag eye young shall see well euer maner growing thriuing power restore vnto good stomacke sound liuer perfect heate shall execute function well euer afore power worketh selfe without body power reason vnderstanding wil may call mynd thou yet still doubt thereof consider thou myndest thing earnestly thy body furthereth mynd abilitie vnderstanding may bee lik ned man though haue lost hand lute ceasseth therefore bee man still doe true deedes man wit discourse thing mynd vse reason like yea luter man afore notwithstanding cannot put luteplaying exercise want instrument nay vnderstanding part groweth much stronger greater lesse occupyed busied bace corruptible thing altogether drawen home wholly selfe seene want eye whose mynds commonly apt vnderstand firme remember doe debate thing selues neither body sences busied doe wee little doe stirre vnderstand operation mynd soule hath neede bodie working accompany one another sayth aristotle therefore continue still soule hath doe body neede body rather woorke well well soule ought eyther without bodie leastwise vtterly vnsubiect bodie yea say yet see men forgoe reason fooles mealancholike person seeing forgone may also bee corrupted corrupted may also dye death vtter full corruptnesse nay thou shouldest say rather haue seene diuers hauing seemed haue lost right wittes haue recouered againe good dyet medicinable drinkes bene vtterly lost forgone phisicke could haue restored agayne bene vtterly perished party themselues haue neither sence life remayning therefore necessitie sould sound afore soules wee see otherwise bodie instrument bodie spectacle mynd beholdeth seeth imagination clowde sort trubbled dimining spectacle smoakinesse imagination maner sunne seemeth dimmed eclipsed comming moone clowdes betweene v light abatement likewise eysight conceyueth thing according spectacle wherethrough looketh according colour ouerthwarteth thing looketh vpon ta away impediment eye shall see cleere purge away humour imagination shall bee pure vnderstanding shall see bright afore euen sunne shineth putting away clowdes fareth soules doth body long sicknesse reteyne still eyther hardnesse splene shortnesse breath falling rhewme vppon lung skarre great wound cannot bee worne breake made whole neither vnderstanding neither willes soules feele abatement sauing abydeth mayme blemish instrument wit declare hereafter farre foorth pleaseth god iust punishment put soule subiection bodie whose souereyne created haue bene hath neglected creator followe lustes lykings bodie appeareth lunaticke folkes others haue wittes troubled tymes fittes vexed stirring humour beeing tymes sober well enough stayed wittes like seene haue falling sicknesse vnderstanding seemeth eclipsed striken thunderclap tyme fittes afterward bee discreete though ayled nothing bee short body subiect thousand disease wherewith wee see vnderstanding bee whit altered touch instrument sences imagination moue vnderstanding troubled deede fewe thing infect sence imagination meanes report thing vnfaithfully whereon mynd debateth therfore ye shall neuer see bodie wittes right mynd phisitions may manifestly perceyue eyther default instrument mishapen misproportioned head el ouerabounding melancholike humour troubled marred bodie afore troubled impayred mynd like wisest men deceyued false spyes make worng deliberation howbeit yet grounded vpo good reason thing could doe vnlesse wise deede reason mynd maketh false discourse gathereth wrong conclusion vppon false report imagination could doe eyther diminished impayred done away whereunto accordeth auncient saying bee certeyne follyes none wise men commit certeyne error none learned men fall case discretion wisedome requisite partie deceyued euen intent may bee deceyued learning required man may conceyue hold wrong opinion example beguyled dubbledealing spy surprising cosening letter belongeth none wise man grosheaded foole neuer breaketh brayne matter might bring making false conclusion mistaking likelyhoods stead truth likewise fall heresie misconceyuing high deepe poynt befalleth ignorant person capacitie neyther doth vnderstanding mount high short whosoeuer sayth man soule perisheth bodie troubled distemperature misproportionatenesse bodie may well vphold child moothers wombe dyeth moother moueth partaker harmes throwes reason streyt coniunction betweene howbeit many child haue liued safe sound notwithstanding moothers haue dyed yea haue come world euen death moothers whereas say mynd conceyueth thing helpe imagination therfore imagination gone instrument whereunto tyed soule cannot worke alone self cosequently alone selfe surely al one say child moothers wombe taketh nourishment blud nauill therfore cannot liue whe come womb nauillstrings cut nay contrarywise tyme mouth tongue part childe doe duetie serued erst purpose sauing prepared tyme come maner also doe wee cherish mynd imagination second life third life ye would say scaped prison shall begin vtter operation himselfe much certeynly shall subiect false report sences eyther inward outward thing themselues shall haue seene learned bee short shall liue prison shall see spectacle shall vnderstand report shall list way lusting infirmitie bodie casteth vpon shall bee away force bringeth body shal fresh liuely afore notwithstanding vayn reason let v conclude soule vnderstanding reasonable power ouer neither death corruption haue naturally power although fitted body gouerne man doubt hereof let examine himselfe euen owne doubt proue vnto stand contention stil let fall reasoning himselfe concluding argument proue soule mortall shall giue iudgement himselfe immortall haue left thing vnalledged might make purpose may seeing euen selfsame thing haue bin able alledge behalf myne aduersaries driue thereunto let v thinke also feeleth conuicted himselfe whose behoofe benefite greatly beleeue confesse needeth diligent proofe hath bene made alreadie man yet spyght stand wilfully still himselfe let trye make answer foresayd argument meane let v see sayd opinion wisest men yea whole world hath bene vpon mater xv chapter immortalitie soule hath bene taught philosopher old tyme beleeued people nation soothly bene harde case mynd searcheth many thing nature power growing perceiuing sences ioyned maner body therfore followeth vnderstanding power ioyned also consequently according aristotle euery body hath forme euery body hath soulearistotle first booke soule aristotle findeth fault former philosopher holding opinion soule might passe one man another sayeth euery certeyne soule must needes apportioned appoynted one certeine body looke soule man liueth soule doth vnderstand one soule indued three diuers ability hee himselfe teacheth opently one vnderstauding mynd therefore must according aristotle worke one seuerall body many bodyes also defining beast man auerrhoes also holdeth without doubting thereof conclusion therfore cannot anywise vpheld ground againe bee euery seuerall man seuerall mynd onely one vniuersall mynd common men partes world doe followe nature nature itselfe teacheth v sayd man onely falne state wherein set lower degree afore also falne himselfe himselfe owne peculiar nature moreouer manifest world created man vse world knoweth selfe creature therein ageine angel needed brute beastes haue skill vse onely man hath vnderstanding vse seruice thereof body hath neede seruice sith doubt god created man knowledge creature also gaue power ouer whereof commeth beastes doe naturally knowe season remedy disease herbes haue proprietie nature heale man among liuing thing knoweth insomuch fayne goe schoole brute beastes learne also whereof commeth creature surely god made snare man bene repugnant goodnes creator man benefite seruice doe kicke spurne ageinst man yea euen haue power stregth withstand let v omit woolues leopard lyon seeme haue force ouermatch weakenes man meaneth wormes make v warre within bowel yt vermin deuoureth corne earth yeeldeth v kind fruit hath peculiar enemie marre ere come hand driue v confesse man must needes haue offended maker right greeuously whereas god putting creature subiection man end man haue continued obedience vnto god man hath rebelled god maiestie god also suffereth rebell man put subiection man yea euen kourings earth el contrarietie earth tilleth sea sayleth aire successe labour trauels protestation whole nature disdeineth serue creature presumptuous disobey creator creature say seruice creature hath forgone authoritie receiued maker consequently let v consider man towards manin respect man disordered cotrarie nature nature man himselfe beastes one kind doe kill eate one another wee take ougly thing ouglynesse ought vnto v wee see men alonly indued reason doe euery howre kill one another roote one another nay rather great wonder see good agreement frendship among nation betweene cou try among company euen household yea betweene chamberfellowes wolues cruell yet race wolues shall wee find caribies cannibal lyon also cruell yet euer seene battell one another warre gathering packing vp together sort beastlines world yet common among men beast say barke grunt ere byte house cracke ere fall downe wind whistleth ere breake thing contrariwise man towards man euen laughing threatneth saluting sleaeth vnder faire countenance courteous interteynement cloketh thousand serpent thousand lyon thousand quickesands thousand rockes well let v leaue wicked discouer themselues much doe wee bargayning buying selling beguyle one another doe dalying delude one another el whole societte man highly commend selfgaine incroching one vppon another greater sort tyrant vppon meaner meaner vpon inferiour sort inferiour sort one vppon another take trippe bee short wee doe good end bee seene asfor secret wee doe none ageine wee forbeare doe euill feare least world knowe feare away wee would stick nothing wherto serueth v reason v vnto goodnes couer naughtinesse say make v woorse vnreasonable yet notwithstanding vnreasonable euer wee bee doings cannot knowe reason v could conceiue corrupted swarue yet examine oure selues shalnot bee able deny digresse farre therefore may well deeme reason eysight either impayred inchaunted hath ground sight still yet standeth partie stead onely beguyle false image illusion let v come man himselfeman respect see whether leastwise loue himselfe better men wee stirre shall feele stinche corruption diseased man feeles peine wee say corruption body furthermore default nature partie hath taken great surfet hath brought case nowthen shal say great nomber disease wherwith mankind peyned wherewith wholy ouerwhelmed age life part body small string part flesh hath peculiar disease nay say man alone subiect mo disease liuing thing world togither philosopher sawe haue made bookes expresly thereof vtterly amased graueled seeking cause thereof could neuer yet yeelde reason thereof might satisfie others themselues neuerthelesse parte come point man vnhappiest liuing wight find fault god nature notwithstanding confesse haue doone nothing iustly behalfe one sayes onely man fleaeth himselfe impatience greef another sayes lyfe man death rather bee desired lyfe speech doe schooles ring another great woonderment reckeneth vp certeine hundred disease whereunto eye alone subiect beastes hath much thirtith part body likely god hath giuen man great preheminence aboue creature created purpose torment aboue creature rather sayd man originall created farre another sort whether respect creator himselfe ende hee created surely let v say haue sayde afore cause man alone hath mo disease body creature toogither hee hauing abused god gracious gift hath doone euill could skill doe euill vntowardnes punish man withall example hayle snowe serue hurt earth fruites earth punish take benefite againe come consider soule body knit together number affection doe meete withall saith plutark much sorowfull greeuous bodily disease soule sinfull blameworthie bodie bring passion reasonable order soule fault seeing punishment thereof men whome first fault man originall men v say materially againe fault cannot bee imputed body body selfe hath neither imputed fection receiued first body soule could wrought body soule therefore must fault mankind needes soules offence doth soule suffer punishment make body also suffer howbeit may better iudge opinion let v heare chief one another plotine dealing bace transitorie thing bee short al vertue learned purging soule must fayne newfurbished scoure greate rust hath ouergrowen contradiction therefore hee maketh question himselfeplotin lib enn cap bee cause sayth hee soules diuine nature forget god father kinred themselues surely answereth beginning mischeef certeine rashnes ouerboldnesse wherethrough would needes plucke neckes collar owne commaundement abuse turning libertie licentiousnes went cleane backe farre gone away god like child newly weaned byanby conueyed away father moothers knowe neither whose whence came word agreeth diuines yt corruption came sinplotin enn lib cap also ye kind sinne namely pryde wherby turned away fro maker another place soule saith bred heauenly thing hath plundged itselfe materiall thing matter itselfe euill onely matter matched matter also euen hath respect vnto matter filled euill eye beholdeth darknes filled darknes ye see onely whence turned away also wit god vanitie creator creature good euill inclyning materiall thing sometymes maketh body authorplotin enn lib cap though body caried soule away force imagination acquitteth mynde thereof much insomuch hee sticketh affirme notwithstanding marrednesse yet soule liueth abideth pure cleane godenn lib cap yea euen whyle soule whereof mynd yee would say eisight apple eye dwelleth body howbeit besides reproued porphyrius proclus others owne reason whereby proueth soule naturally subiect body strong vnpossible shift great philosopher ouershot needes seeke cause sinne man man finding reason caried away imagination imagination deceiued sences thought fault haue proceeded wheras deede haue sought cause man first created sences appetite absolutely commaundement whose wilfull offending hath brought vppon v necessitie punishment indure good sooth saying another place cannot interpreted otherwise namely cause soule indureth many trubbles passion body taken life led afore body say subiection soule body originall cause sinne therof rather condemnation thereof punishmentplotin eun lib cap lid cap neither also scape fro conclusion owne namely soule beeing separated body hath wing sound perfect body ioyned soule hath power breake wing yet findeth weake without wing except hold v soule hath fall forgone strength body feeblenes soule sentence creator strengthened weakenesse wit much body haue sayde afore house become prison soule short graunting god iustice doth hee neuer wind himselfe question maketh namely sinnes imputed soule seeing doth infection body vnlesse make infection punishment fault soule committed afore body porphyrius perceyued inconueniences hath spoken distinctly matter mayster agreeing neuerthelesse corruption man austin citie god lib cap cleansing soule cleansing soule sayth needfull thing cannot possibly bee god hath prouided vniuersal meane cleansing mankynd possible sayth fall soule come imagination knitteth soule bodie seeing higher thing drawne downe lower contrarywise lower drawne vp higher nay rather sayth higher substance come downe themselues vnderstanding imagination spirituall thing bodily thing high thing lowe thing fro perfect thing vnperfect thing wheras sticking fast vnto god might haue abidden firme much owne strength might haue liued wrought vnder forme bee come fall themselues stooping matter therfore porphyrius booke sheweth thing conceyued alonly reason vnderstanding sayth substaunces inclinable thing befalne men say sinne certeyne vnbeleef condemned fell loue creature turned away creator short commeth poynt fall men soules like fall feendes taught iewes fault wit termeth vnbeleefe vnfaithfulnesse man falne folly concupiscence sayalso third booke abstinence fault punishment thereof rebellion soule bondage thereof bodie ye must thinke wee speake contrary wee say one man sinned aduauncing high presuming become equall god another sinned stooping downe bace lowe thing deede lifting vp man selfe godward true abacing humbling himselfe hee rightly looke vp god make account himselfe rather bee abaced himselfe inclyne man selfe trueth presuming make himselfe equall god seeking thing selues bee found god namely welfare felicitie el pride selfestimation ouerweening man selfe proclus proclus concerning soule concerning feend cap doth ordinarily call inclyning nature vnto euill descending comming downe corruption thereof fall highest soule atteyne vnto beholding god descending stooping comming downe thereof fall estimation selues fall bee thrust downe subiectio vnder selues like body falleth high place touching cause corruption fathereth vppon mynd wit highest part soule saying continued sound sticked fast vnto god sayth plotin also hild reason sound still sunbeame thereof consequently action haue bene found wee haue bene subiect sinne seeing punishment come euen highest part v see combered many passion dimmed much darknesse defiled many vyces surely fault proceeded onely thence herevnto might ad many saying wee content selues onely simplicius simplicius vppon epictus famous interpreter aristotle long man soule sayth cleaueth fast vnto god author thereof abydeth sound holdeth perfection wherwith created god fall shrinking away withereth hauing lost roote come nothing neyther recouer former liuelynesse except reunited agayne former cause perceyue euerychone v nature withered therefore let v say slipped roote roote leaueth braunches contrarywise braunches leaue roote let v say haue bereft ourselues gracious goodnesse god would haue mainteyned v still nourish quicken propertie nature roote one thing doe philosopher differ v behalfe namely vphold men soules haue sinned euery one himselfe wee say onely first man sinned thereby hath bound whole ofspring punishment yet doe come backe agayne one poynt seeing euen owne reason proued creation world necessitie leadeth v one man father v whereas philosopher hang wauering still vnresolued poynt among people wee see prayer craue pardon sinnevniuersall consent sacrifice appease god wrath misticall washing satisfactories uotaries sinnes whole realme citie haue sayd afore publick protestation publick herevppon call remembrance creation man woman scripture god sayth vnto increase multiply fill earth haue giuen al hearb bearing seede tree bearing fruite foorth sayth booke diuinitie men prouoked word sweate thy browes shalt thou eate thy bread day thy life bee ignorant god euen knowe wee esteeme bee almost another kynd wicked perceyuing themselues want matter replyeobiections fail rayling god maketh thee vnreasonable thy sences seruice doest thou put marring thy sences thy tongue much eloquet speaking euill speaking good bee short shal good thing become hath giuen thee maintenance thy health life nay contrary part thou turnest thy death thy bane founder blame thou kill thy self thing without thou couldest liue thou become euill thing without thou couldest good god hath giuen thee without thou couldest bee good unto hee hath added good wit guyde without wit thou couldest wise thou loth eyther good wise thou art loth bee man thy giuen thee loue god withall loue delighteth bee freeharted neither would god bee loued v inchaunted freely vtterly vnconstreined therfore behoued free likewise thy wit giuen thee behold god withall haddest thou onely thy sences haddest thou brute beastes thou haddest whole world made thee two canst thou finde fault seeing without thou couldest neither good wise man thou wouldest haue bin created vnchaungeable howbeit rock mountayne man surely vnchaungeablenesse spirit created depend vppon linking maker thou wouldest peraduenture haue bin angel euen angel falne thei farre higher thou fall daungerous thyne man acknowledge goodnes creator creating thee good acknowledge vanitie creature cannot stand owne goodnesse goodnesse creator especially aboue thing commend thou goodnesse mercie hath onely releeued thee thy fall also vphild thee thou mightest fall softer another taketh exception god iustice iustice sayth punish man rigorously small fault nay iust nature naturall runne darknesse man turneth away sunne plotin sayth impayre wex naught man departeth souereyne good thou man thinkest thy self iuster god punishment wouldest thou appoynt thy sonne babe yoong childe come yeeres discretion mangrowen pinched pyned flowing wealth vpon brauerie lustinesse courage would disobey thee thing nothing set thou adam also thyne eye newly come world goodnesse creator starke naked furnished ye whole world serue witlesse pure sound skilfull mynd subiect lustes able holde awe hauing obedient reason whether thou consider sinne rebellion vnfaithfulnes pride whether thou haue eye easines absteyning sinne punishment wilt thou deeme worthie haue yea sayest thou vseth rigour child nay rather say mercifull gracious keepe low father fall least fall greeuously rashnesse thou buildest citie custome beautifie priuiledges afterward citie rebelleth thou take away priuiledges belle armour weapon punishment insurrection extendeth posteritie albeit fewe beginning grewe bee mightily multiplyed afterward graunting priuiledges first poynt goodnesse otherwise might haue occasion complayne thee likewise iustice take mercie withhold posteritie haue rebellious mynd el runne headlong extreme punishment god gaue thee priuiledge freedome inriched thee singular gift body mynd praise thou goodnesse thou hast abused eyther taketh cleane away el diminisheth acknowledge thou iustice thy child might doe thou hast done would amended thine example taketh also diminisheth thee commend thou still mercie iustice specially honor thou iustice mercie rebellious race hee causeth partie bee borne appease iustice yet giue ouer sinne first proceeded farre say roote wherby felicitie come atteind vnto faith fayth god beleeuing welfare lyeth beleeuing hoping hope desiring desire hauing bee short continuall beleef heere bewraying heere neither haue see haue faith haue ignorance haue faith haue wee onely desire longing considering greater fayth wee despise bace thing greater desire hate selues earnestly doe loue god short fayth welfare behighted would see faith way vnto felicitie would possesse inioy looke proportion betweene present come proportion betwixt hope haue heere yea euen aboue world aboue selues perfect full fruition good seeke atteine vnto let v feaw word gather togither wee haue said heretofore whereas wee seeke ende restingpoint world made man man soule soule mynd mynd much higher thing self el god vnderstand concerning god naturall wisdome ignorance conceiue supernaturall power beleefe beleefe maketh thing perfect moueth vnderstanding followeth doings haue end rest vpon life come beholding knowing god againe wee seeke souereine good appetite owe obedience reason perfection reason knowing god contentment possessing god possesse god farre foorth wee loue loue farre foorth knowe neither ignorance ingender earnest loue beleefe ingender full perfect fruition onely certeyne hope hope matched impatience euen best v followeth therefore cannot inioye souereine welfare vntill bee come vtmost end haue full contentation vntill wee haue full knowledge wit wee cannot haue world man two cannot content mynd satisfie forsomuch eyther world wretchednesse though wee haue dubble life yet haue vtmost restingpoynt onely souereine welfare nowwhere el onely god euerlasting life declare felicitie man shalbe come vtmost restingpoynt wilbee rash open mouth yt behalf hath told v neither eye hath seene hart conceyue knowe vnable eyther see haue therefore one word let v contented desire shalbe satisfied day seeing extend thing god shall day see haue knowe thing yet larger confirmation peraduenture outward man one would rob god one halfe man dooing hipocrisie high treason god ageine seeing religion byndeth v great bond euen nature man inforced confesse dette witnessed whole worlde surely man feeleth himselfe able pay doth willingly pleade giltie yea inforced say part thought word deedes farre god also tending directly offend god religion offer v well meane whereby discharge cancell bond offereth v bond selfe farre way welfare ought bee rather definitiue sentence death expresse condemning v therfore let v see whether many wayes satisfaction onely one shall deuoutest man releeued dette v one sort nature namely owe selues wholy vnto god vnabilitie discharge also alyke namely euer commeth selues deserue nothing death vpon death common bond say entred v god benefites towards first man disobedience become forfeted respect himselfe mankind besides creditor payer one cannot one onely god doth satisfie followeth true religion one namely euen one sheweth v onely one meane saluation religion abate whit man debt vnto god traiterous maiestie set downe sufficient meane discharge vayne vnauaylable ceremony well one sort vtterly vnworthy name religion furthermore diuers true religion meane diuers respect substance whereof riseth diuersitie thing poynt nay god religion looketh vnitie maner vnitie diuersitie respect bee one religion relye vpon one god another vpon another sure one god god either creature uanities insomuch proclus himselfe saith mo god god differ nothing atall shal religion either idolatrie atheisme say vtter godlesnes whereof ground nay man ground whereon religion worketh one kind thing also disease men commeth one roote one selfsame nature likewise remedie thereof haue sayd already one ground one disease one remedie one euer say bee diuersitie artes handling ministring man bee humble himselfe would fayne haue tell way know himselfe way knowe himselfe behold himselfe way behold himselfe looke faire cleare glasse clearer glasse lawe god perfect obedience god requireth man hand seeing lawe perfect obedience required one may religion diuided mo one ageine man lifted vp vnto god way make knowe god creator may honor gouernour may call vppon father may obey altogither iust hee may seeke appease wrath thing sith hee cannot doe himselfe shift hath haue recourse remedie seeing remedie bee onely one doth follow saluation lyeth onely religion sheweth vnto v haue mo religion confusion vanitie speake properly religion arte skil may terme saue men wherein consisteth arte first shewing men disease secondly shewing deadly finally teaching fit conuenient remedie deede law nature leadeth v well first poynt hee euen nature accuseth himselfe whose conscience nippeth hee hath sinned reason also leadeth v second poynt hee concludeth himselfe creature offendeth creator deserueth rooted say sinne ingendreth death thus farre may religion come ceremony ordeyned man praiers sacrifice wasshins cleansing others bnt bringging v hellgate rather shewing paradise vnto v farre howbeit horrible infinite gulfe betwixt v man whole world neither fill vp passe ouer yet must needes passage end man vnited vnto god end vaine meane vnited aboue reconcyled beneath meane reconcyled beneath haue sayd alreadie onely one god himselfe acquit v without discharging debt wee owe vnto onely religion none leadeth v streight said passage following whereof find true religion allonly atteineth ende religion sauing man may men wil say worship god diuersly lifting vp eye heauen othersome casting face downe ground yes worshipping one humbling men selues one still though bee difference signes disputing ceremony substance also may men offer sacrifice diuersly yes thy sacrifice haue ende sheading blud beast sayth hierocles fyre feeding thereof fewell vapor preestes superfluous maintenance butcherie requisite therefore sacrifice bee referred somewhat namely thou shouldest protest whereas sillie innocent beastes doo suffer death thou thy selfe hast deserued body soule againe thou haue nothing el thy religion sacrifice prayer goodly showe soeuer make thou hast nothing confession thy fault sentence death thee ceremony aime certein marke trifling toyes end whereat aime come short doe leade thee vnto death leaue thee would beare v handan obiection religion obseruation certeyne ceremony euery countrie reason holy vnholy another place godly one land vngodly another short make lyke lawes depend vppon custome passe bound place vsed religion nothing else science art trade vayne rather sayd deede religion leachecraft vncerteine many respect aire water age clymate yet ye leachecraft one countrie manquelling another lawecraft hath almost many sundry lawes caces caces world infinite yet notwithstanding seeth diuersities caces brought vnder one vpryghtnes reason yeeld thereunto reputed men rather enemy mankynd wyld beast also vertue hath affection woorke vpon ground mouable sea wind yet wil say hardines betweene tropiks cowardlines countryes yt stayednesse one half world vnstayednesse half short thing subiect rising falling cryed downe inhaunced coyne siluer gold seemeth followe willes prince yet notwithstanding ordinance proclamation gold siluer alwayes keepe certeine rate valew shall say religion hath firmer substantialler ground meane mennes body good affection fantasy soule mynd man also hath rest stay vppon settled vnmouable lord chaunges wit god much wysely doth pythagorist hierocles teache v religion gouernesse vertewes vertewes tend certeine end would say vertewes swarue insomuch hardynesse referred godlynesse becommeth rashnesse wisedome becommeth wylynes lynes iustice becommeth iuggling woord vertue masking hipocrisie religion end vertewes must need fixed vnmouable mouable iust good vertuous case stand thing world vnauaylable man speake ryghtly thing lesse purpose man mynd vertue wickeddest man auow therefore also certeine religion maketh vertue whereunto vertue referreth vngodlyest man cannot scape let v looke yet absurdity opinion denie among diuersities religion many sort wickednes vngodlynes openly executed woorshipping creature heauen yea earth egiptians old time tartarians day offering vp men sacrifice carthaginenses old tyme westerne iles yet day othersome permitting thing contrarie lawes also euen horrible lothsome nature good pray good rather euill world euill deny wicked vngodly religion world vse woord religion comon maner man neede rule whereby discerne good religion bad verie deede rooted nature beleeue one religion well beleeue one god may daily see man rather indure change temperate aire extreme whot extreme cold freedom bondage iustice tyrannye alteration atall though neuer little case religion verily would say naturall man loue natiue countrie free easie haue one certeine religion gwyde saluation meaning hath bin lay foorth trueth mo sort purpose take away doubt auoyde krinks inuented anew certeine libertine forasmuch many ceremony disguise selues attire religion deceyue vsthe first mark true religion needfull v haue sure infallible mark whereby discerne true religion first therefore let v lay foundation haue layd settled alreadie heretofore namely religion ryght rule seruing god reconcyling reuniting man agein vnto god may saued man saluation nothing el felicitie happynes souereyne good welfare welfare haue declared afore knit vnto god neither world creature world make man happye made man cleare case wee ought serue heere beneath make v happie aboue none religion therefore goodly showe euer haue eye turneth away seruing god seruing creature idolatrie vngodlynes vnto v also religion causeth v seeke welfare anywhere el maker welfare wilbe vnto v vanitie thrusting v way also murthering ourselues casting v headlong wretchednes may well haue offering first fruit thanksgiuings seruices iniuries blasphemy ageinst god wee think ourselues beholden creature thing neither haue haue creator also may well haue prayer sacrifice prayer shalbe vayne vngodly made cannot impute gouernment world vnto creature see scarsly see thing afore asfor sacrifice shalbe smokie sauours yea ful trayterous trecherie god confesse lyues dead thing make amends creature offence haue committed ageinst creator therefore let first marke true religion seeke direct v churchseruices vnto true god maker heauen earth searcher men heart thing wherewith wil cheefely serued may distinguish idolatry seeke vnto wood stone sunne moone men angells creature heauen earth needfull heape vp greate nombers proof repeate agein thing haue bin discoursed second third chapter woorke sith one god one religion also thing agreeable nature referre wholly creator verie deede plotin porphyrius proclus iamblichus others worshipped angel good spirit thought sayd wherein neuerthelesse vnexcusable atteyne degree highest god sayd marke alone fuffice vsthe second marke true religion wee must serue god must also serue aright rule seruice set downe writing may serue aright behoueth v know aright v vaunt many bee long studie much tell v followeth lyke wizdome world cannot without ouerthrowe selfe atteyne concerning god say hee wizdome may well atteine farre discerne seruing god false set downe poynt true seruice atteyne knowledge godhead country cloyne shalbe skorned labour take vpon appoynt prince serued yet man well prince differing prince state calling atall nature kind sayd man woorme yea lesse woorme respect euerlasting god hee needes shape serue owne fancie philosopher say god ought bee serued diuine passe somewhat say serued vapor smoakes sheading blud hath euer sayd god spirit serued spirit haue come thing neere wyde hath wandered away ageine came particular poynting seruice trueth worshippings god man hath ordeyned owne head childish imagination onely vnbeseeming maiestie god also inferiour discretion man gaming showes stageplayes ronnings horse iusts thousand sort combat swordplayings wrestling buffeting doth betoken man mounteth aboue man thinketh flye lightest pitch scarce heaueth himselfe vpright vppon feete neuer riseth aboue earth man hee calling witts looking aduisedly vnto selfe could find heart bee honored serued maner surely let v say looke farre god voutsafeth stoope vnto v farre able mount vp vnto comming downe mounting vp cannot see sonne helpe sonne welsighted euer much lesse god seene knowen v without help light god short cannot serue god except knowe knowe except voutsafe discouer himselfe v therefore wee knowe serue worship furtherfoorth listeth shewe vnto v word yet discouering vnto v needeth neither drawe v vp brightnes come downe v maiestie mynds could abyde eye away beholding sonne hee must fayne stoope small abilitie telling v seruice requireth hand according spirituall nature cannot possibly comprehend glasse scarf according ye fleshly nature beare v thus haue found second marke religion namely seruice god religion teach v must grounded vppon word reuealed vnto v ownselfe let v heare heathen say case knewe well ladder philosophie short reache thereunto behoued men inlightened instructed aboue diuinitie saith plato plato second epistle parmenides cannot laydforth maner kind seruing hath neede continuall mynding wit foorthwith kindled fyre afterward gathereth light maynteineth selfe finally sayth know nothing god matter owne skill auncient philosopher saw cleere confesse sight faileth much ayded aboue may deeme others good sooth matter religion sendeth v euermore auncient oracle say according meaning god wordaristotle examined would haue sayde lesse concerning religion certaine saith iamblicus iamblichus bound thing please god surely sayth possible knowen man hath heard god himselfe speake haue learned heauenly instruction alpharabius arabian agreeth thereunto wordsalpharabius booke science thing concerne god beleeued holy fayth higher degree thing proceede diuine inspiration man wit weake reason short attayne therefore reade haue ordeined stablished religion nation haue giuen foorth proceeding god verily nature taught belongeth none god alone appoynt hee shalbe serued neither would ordinance therof otherwise obserued party obey would make great account theselues partie inioyne thus definitiue sentence philosopher second marke standeth firme serue v discerne true religion inuentions men may well refuse vntrueth whatsoeuer grounded vpon god word following former purpose let v consider yet whether suffice nothe third marke true religion haue neede lawe proceedeth god mouth may pray proceedeth holynesse self namely holy holy cannot selues know god ought serued ala shall performe hath declared vnto v ende religion sayeth plato knit man vnto god way bring passe become rightuous holy saith iamblichus offer vnto god cleane mynd voyd naughtines cleere spot man euen themselues confesse could euer vaunt therof el religion v booke wherein reade sentence death wit death deede vnlesse ende wee find grace forgiuenesse sinnes yet notwithstanding religion pathway life yea euen eternall life pathway hath certeyne ende beguyleth v therefore must meanes fill v vp great gulfe betweene endlesse death endlesse life betweene dwellingplace blessednes horriblenes hell therefore let third marke religion must put hand meane satisfie god iustice without onely religion also euen conteineth true seruing true god vtterly vayne vnprofitable man reason hath well perceiued meane needefull religion knowe meane high thing man reason atteyne vntoo respect whereof platonist busied themselues much finding meane cleanse men sinnes knit vnto god beeing reconciled fauour set downe certeine degree wherby atteine therunto yet end confesse washing clensings vtterly vnsufficient say bee done abstinence vertuous behauiour skill iupiters mystery say done al successiuely one another yet haue bestirred themselues side porphyrius conclusion ceremony without effect yet notwithstanding must necessitie needes meane purge iustifie men must bee vniuersall possible admitting god prouidence ought doe god leaue mankind destitute meane remedie ought conteyne din religion hee sheweth sufficiently hee seeketh taking order consecration hallowings misteries owne religion end letteth go againe yet apparantly doth hierocles shewe ithierocles chapter preface sayth religion studie wisedome consisteth clensing perfecting life men may one god become like vnto atteyne cleanesse meane enter man owne conscience consider sinne confesse vnto god thus farre well neuerthelesse stoppe ouershort euerychone vppon confession inseweth death vnlesse god iustice selfe infinitely contrary euill imagine appeased satisfied offence whereas religion seeke life bee short great nomber religion
